title: Leadership Problems
pros: Used to be a great place to work. Good wages, benefits and employees felt respected.
cons: Lots of favoritism and nepotism from the top down. Chances for advancement are limited by the fact that jobs often go to a personal friend or office favorite of the hiring manager. Squeaky wheels always get the oil. Managers don't know how to have the hard conversations with employees who need it, so the good employees are the ones who suffer. Tenured employees are not appreciated or respected,

title: Get in while you can!
pros: Crown Castle as an organization is growing exponentially, but still holds the importance of its profound culture and workforce in its heart. I've been with the company for 5 years, and I've seen people drive their own success and really develop themselves to fit a multitude of roles--which helps people not get stuck in one linear career path. I'm glad I found Crown Castle (or, well they technically found me) because instead of just being a stepping stone or resume builder, I'm excited for a long and fruitful career here. Bring on 5G and the internet of things!!
cons: Nothing really comes to mind.

title: Director
pros: It used to be the bonus and stock, but in light of the fact that the company cannot seem to keep up with our two biggest competitors, I suspect that will be changing as well.
cons: The company has become genocidal with respect to any employees over 40. There has been a troubling trend over the last couple of years of "quietly" getting rid of any employees that are over 40 through a "early retirement" program. How this works, is they basically fire you under the guise of an "early retirement" so they can make way for younger and more expensive politically connected friends of the management team. Not sure how the people running HR received their jobs (just kidding-all politically connected in Houston) in light of their clear ignorance of the law. I would highly advise any potential candidates that are over 40 to stay far away from this place or become part of a pattern of mercy killings.

title: Very happy at this company
pros: Solid salary. Great culture, lots of company paid social events for employees. Lots of growth opportunities and the ability to move up in the company is there. Work-life balance is a priority. Great people to work with everyday. Employees are encouraged to make decisions and offer suggestions on how to improve the way the company operates. Company has seen tremendous growth in past 10 years and it appears like that trend will continue.
cons: My training was very minimal, almost non-existant. Workload can get overwhelming at times.

title: What a difference a bad manager can make!
pros: Casual work environment, competitive pay, good benefits, and amazing coworkers.
cons: Management change a few years ago totally changed the environment of the office. She was inconsistent, inaccessible and played favorites to a great extent. Very difficult to keep up morale under her “leadership”. Those who work(ed) under her management knew she would not have your back if something went wrong. Completely out for herself with little regard for others.

title: Deteriorating culture
pros: Immediate team is great. Great benefits and PTO. Hybrid schedule.
cons: Jay Brown and the EMTs. They have destroyed the trust and culture of the company. they went from employee focused to wall street investors and woke agenda. If you are a male, good luck getting promoted. Pay is below avg. The executive talks down to everyone. They are fake and only care about their bonuses. They removed the old board members who focused on company culture and employee focus. that is gone. I used to say this was the company I recommend to work for, now I am looking to leave.

title: Rewarding work, great benefits, pleasant environment
pros: 1. I seriously work with the most talented, light-hearted, and hardworking individuals. The work environment is very pleasant and management encourages a healthy work/life balance. 2. The health benefits are generous and wonderful. 3. The core values encourage creativity, perpetual learning, and individual accountability
cons: 1. Offers, promotions, and performance reviews could happen in a more timely manner; multiple levels of approvals seem to be contributing to the sluggish pace. 2. Salary doesn't seem to be adjusted for the local market ranges; Crown Castle's headquarters is in Houston and the HR Department is in Pittsburg, PA so the salaries for employees in the Silicon Valley aren't as competitive as they should be.

title: Management is lacking in the East
pros: The people that work with you on a day to day basis. They were the reason I stayed as long as I did. PMs, CMs, RESs, Sales’, TSAs, and management in assets is solid. Asset Managers and the director of assets in the East are not only true leaders but they are also good people that care about their direct reports. Real Estate Acquistion (REA) is also a great place to work, you will never work in the East area again as the East operates in a vacuum from the rest of Crown and you are considered a “traitor” if you go work for another area or REA. Not to discourage you from taking that role, if you are lucky enough to get into REA that is based out of Houston grab that position and never let go.
cons: The rest of the departments once you get over a level 6 the talent is truly lacking. Some of the directors, one in particular is one of the most oppressive human beings I have encountered. He belittled and mocked employees as a “joke” on a regular basis. I am not sure how promotions of people like that are continuing and I can only assume that it is coming from the top in the area. He is not the only one though, it would be quicker to list the director deserving of her position who is both fair and respectful with her employees. Though there is only so much she can do when surrounded by unethical peers. Employees are terrified to speak out. Surveys are given but no one believes them to be anonymous. Dishonesty on the surveys is the only option as many believe they will be fired if they speak out. I would like to mirror the review that stated that the management particularly in the East needs to be re-evaluated, Crown lost so many good employees because they have lazy and unethical management running rampant. When upper management has nicknames like the Queen of Hearts, Hitler, and Mussolini there is a real problem. Any company should be embarrassed and horrified at those comparisons of just one in upper management, but three, it is shameful.

title: Optimistic
pros: Total benefit package, working parent flexibility, company trending with technological advances so we stay ahead of the curve and lead in the nation to support the revolution of 5g.
cons: Among the employees, not leadership, it feels as if we have lost our footing with culture and priorities. Culture is dependent on everyone upholding our standards but through the multiple acquisitions the message doesn't seem to have translated well.

title: A case study in the Peter Principle
pros: Great Benefits Very Secure People are generally very nice on a personal level
cons: - Processes are horrible. People manage the milestones, not the actual projects - American Tower is performing much better as a company - Employees are not held accountable. - Lots of project managers focus on service revenue, not rental revenue. - LOTS of excuses are present throughout all levels of the company (its the customer's fault, its the jurisdiction's fault, its pick a department's fault) - Because the business model is so great, there is no sense of true urgency for change. Management has tried multiple projects but they never follow through 100% creating confusion among the workforce and not actually impacting the business) - Because of how complex and cumbersome the internal systems are, it can take while to promote. There is also no standardization. Different teams do the process differently throughout the country.

title: Lots of fun!
pros: I am having a lot of fun working here. They have great benefits and are really good to all the employees. If you need something, they will find a way to make it happen. Very friendly atmosphere and easy to fall into a grove. They like to eat a lot and laugh a lot! Really happy with my new job! This is a great company to work for!
cons: They grew really quickly so the training is a bit rough. They went from a smaller/midsize company to a mid/large size company very quickly. This has cause the obvious stretch marks in the structure. Easy enough to handle though.

title: Was a good company
pros: Great benefits, good culture. Nice offices, transparent at times.
cons: Focus has changed from taking care of employees to who you can get rid of. Hiring people outside the company that go against everything they preach about culture. Constant reorganization. Course correcting a bad business decision made a few years ago that cost them a lot in the immediately.

title: Great place to work and employee focused
pros: Crown Castle has great benefits and the work environment is filled with helpful people who are open to new ideas. Crown Castle is a company with it's priorities in order and where employees are encouraged to thrive. This company is very team oriented and management has been very supportive.
cons: As with any new venture, Crown Castle is working diligently to be come the premier provider in the Small Cell and DAS industry. With that comes some growing pains, but they are easing daily.

title: Great benefits, very political cultural
pros: Get to wear jeans everyday, give you flex time, allow you to take computer home, has an on site gym, matches 6% 401K, puts $1,000 in HSA, 15 days of PTO, 10 paid holidays, very competitive benefits wise.
cons: Very political. Hard work will move you forward, but who you make friends with will move you faster. Very unfair to witness, the "B3 culture" is not truly practiced. If you are not meeting expectations, there will be no discussion of it, you will all of a sudden be let go with no warning. They do not truly develop employees. Benefits are good, however, pay is low for the job title.

title: Disappointed
pros: Healthcare Benefits and 401 (K)
cons: Leadership promotes “being real” and transparent but they really are not. Company conversation answers are pretty vague in my opinion. For example someone asked Jay if it was true about the rumors of a new office building. He flat out said no but if there was he would let us know. A few months later there was an announcement about it. I feel like Jay could have said it’s something they are looking into but decisions have not been finalized. It’s hard to trust what they say is real or political answers. Mid level managers get there by befriending higher leadership personnel although they lack leadership qualities. No mentoring or care for direct reports. Crown says it’s proud of its culture but it’s like a sinking ship. Sadly no diversity! If anything there will be teams of all whites and one minority’s race just to say “we are diverse”. When asked about diversity Jay said Laura Nichol makes their executive team diverse (all white males with one white female.) Pay is not transparent. Employees are slowly finding out the compensation, bonus and PTO varies even though same position and work load are the same. Makes us feel unappreciated and cheated. No flexibility. Crown Castle does not trust employees to work from home at least once a week. Only certain people of course can work from home some days of the week, week of holidays, leave home early on Friday’s, etc. Exempts get away with not using PTO until it’s the end of year and use it all during holidays. Christmas Eve is not a holiday. Does not allow me to spend time with my family who IS off during this holiday. I was told to utilize my PTO although I am at the lowest rate of PTO and have to ration my time off during the year for personal sick days, daughters sick days, family vacations. Religious holidays, etc. While others with less experience are accruing at the max rate and like I mentioned before can get away with not tracking PTO properly.

title: No longer the best company
pros: Benefits are ok, PTO is great, and they pay well.
cons: Crown Castle used to care about their employees, you used to get promoted based off of what you know and how hard you work rather than who you know. Seniored employees are opting to retire early or leave because as long as you are friends with upper management or suck up to upper management, they will move you into management jobs whether you are qualified or not. I see so many qualified people that are being looked over and lied to because upper management already has someone in mind for positions that they are not qualified for. The advice to get ahead is to become friends with Directors and higher ups- MidWest Area is Well known for doing this . The company keeps taking away the reasons why people loved Crown to begin with. The bonus structure changed and not to our benefit, budget cuts makes the company no longer a work hard play hard meaning there are no rewards to your long days anymore. It used to be if you had an exceeds you would get a pay raise and be able to top out your bonus, they no longer do this and wonder why they score low on “ pay for performance” questions on the employee survey. You used to never hear of people wanting to leave or look elsewhere for employment and it’s way more common now than ever. They will not budge on working remotely although they are a telecommunications company. The office politics are just not worth it. To save money they are enforcing a do more with less structure meaning, they aren’t in a hiring freeze but you must really be struggling in order for them to backfill a position. Since they started doing this, there has been minimal movement in the company so when someone is just moved into a position without opening a job requisition, it’s noticeable. There is just not a lot of legitimate opportunities anymore.

title: The best experience of my career
pros: In my experience, it is rare to work for a company with excellence and integrity in leadership, business model and thinking. In 5 years, I have learned a ton and done the best work of my career, while feeling respected and appreciated and working with a great team. I've also been promoted with additional responsibility and constantly challenged, which has led to personal and professional growth. I am deeply thankful to be here and hope to stay and contribute for a long time.
cons: No company is perfect. This is as good as I've seen. The pace of change is rapid and we are evolving constantly. This works for me, but it might not for everyone.

title: Stable and Secure
pros: 90 to 95% of Crown's income is contractually obligated at the beginning of the year. Crown compensates it's employees well and there is job security once you are established as a trusted employee. Crown is a small company with only 5,000 employees, yet is in the top 100 of enterprise value of publicly traded companies. Good benefits and time off is encouraged for work life balance.
cons: There is not much upward mobility. Management positions will mostly go to those with management experience. This isn't a fast growing company with lots of opportunities. The growth is modest and lots of management positions go to outside hires. There is almost zero diversity in the workforce and upper management. It is a white man's world.

title: Production Engineer
pros: Very stable job environment and team building opportunities. Productive and engaging work environment. management treats employees with respect and keeps them informed on the market trends and company position on the market and upcoming upticks and downtrends. Its a completive industry but very positive.
cons: The skillset for an Engineer to continue growing is limited so if you leave the telecomm industry you may have difficulties in other industries in finding employment or growth opportunities. you might get pigeon holed into Telecomm. for your entire career, which is very difficult industry to work in outside of the major players in the market.

title: Such High Hopes, So Disappointed
pros: For the most part, you get to work with smart, generally amiable people - this was an enjoyable part of the company and something you will hear often, the Culture. Leaning in to a transparent framework when it comes to re-orgs & big changes so the employees feel their input is heard.
cons: If you are at a lower-level status, your enthusiasm to succeed and find a place within the company is quickly met with false promises and deflection. There is no line drawn for the demanding workload or expectations as a contractor (such as training formal employees), but once you seek answers or feedback upper management will quickly remind you of your place. There is less of a focus on the work being produced as a top performer, rather your final outcome of advancement is more of a crapshoot of timing and what department you are in. There is proven record of even the most deserving of contracted employees being terminated while the "lucky ones" get to move forward in the employment process. It is well versed by the veteran employees that this is a sad, unreasonable trend that has risen over recent years. Another problem at Crown Castle is that how well you do is more of a matter of perception than the actual work you produce. Even if you're often identified as a good performer -- if you aren't vocal and toot your own horn to management, you are unlikely to advance quickly. You have to be your own advocate, which can be true in most work environments, but for the people who are more interested in focusing on the actual work and demonstrating their value that way, there isn't time partiality. Standards aren't uniformly enforced either. In fact, you will likely spend much of your time learning the daily work and systems on your own. Whether your team is helpful and/or encouraging is a big component of how well you do rather than the company providing the necessary tools and resources to succeed. Unfortunately it sounds like this will be a common factor during your entire time at Crown Castle, as there are so many changes and reorgs that regularly occur.

title: Incredible people and great business model
pros: - The people are caring, humble and dedicated - Truly some of the best people I've ever worked with - Great business model working on 5G and connecting people and communities. The work really matters. - Lots of growth opportunities - Employee benefits are amazing... insurance and 401k. The best 401k company matching program I've ever seen. The company gives a matching contribution equal to 10% of my annual salary to the 401k plan. Amazing!
cons: - Work can be demanding given the nature of network deployments - Systems are not as good as needed for project management. However, the company is making significant investment to make improvements. - Company is so great to work for that few people leave. It can make it seem like there are limited opportunities for promotion

title: Great company to big to fast
pros: Awesome pay , friendly work environment , great benefits. Awsome training opportunities the company will invest in its employees to get them certified in all aspects of their job.
cons: Company has grown so large that they haven’t been able to get their operations straightened out. Logistics and operations on a integration level are lacking. Many fiber acquisitions were made to increase the companies profile and portfolio but didn’t consider the level of impact it would have on current and new employees

title: Great place to work, and even better to have a career - if you can get in
pros: The culture is top notch at Crown, couldn't ask for better people to work with at Crown. Scheduling and hours are flexible for interns, contractors, and employees. I have had the opportunity to work on a variety of projects in the legal department - from lobbying to corporate compliance, to SEC filings and proxy statements. I have been treated with respect and people have gone out of their way to be nice and helpful. Employees and supervisors have been a great help with job-seeking. I would 100% stay if something were to open up. Research projects and other substantive work can be highly rewarding. Legal interns can expect to work on high profile projects from time to time. No one is hanging over your shoulder to get things done - it is evident that they trust their people and that mentality comes from the top.
cons: Interns, while treated well, are not seen as future employees and very little efforts are made to employ them after graduation (for undergraduates) or the bar exam (for law students). Pay is not competitive ($18.50 for legal interns. $13 for regular interns) for similar jobs and is incongruous with the GPA requirements they demand, particularly when there is no job at the end. Work can on occasion be administrative minutiae because of the sheer volume of matters the legal department has to deal with, but I suppose this is a fact of life. Can sometimes feel very 'corporatey' and hierarchical despite the positive culture.

title: Program Manager
pros: Culture, Opportunity for Growth, Customer Relationships, Leadership Team, Compensation and Benefits... This is a great company with many great leaders who truly care about their staff. Yes, we have grown and yes our culture has adapted and evolved through that growth. We had to adapt and grow to survive. This is especially true for publicly traded companies in a fiercely competitive sector like our own. Those who would wish to retain unnecessary and lavish meetings and over staffed teams should consider this would eventually lead to mass lay offs as it was unsustainable. I applaud the EMT for making the tough decisions and ensuring we evolve to meet our growth commitments. As a tenured employee who has worked hard to grow my career at Crown Castle, I genuinely thank Jay and the team.
cons: I love this company but like any company there are areas improvement: I do wish we were more progressive about remote working flexibility. The policy was just updated and it was disappointing to not see more progression here. Allowing people more flexibility here (maybe a day or two a week at max) would increase moral and alleviate stress both at work and at home. Also, I was disappointed in the way the AI was changed. Not necessarily in the alignment towards company goals with shareholder experience. But, more with the fact that a cap was put on the AI. If we are aligning to our shareholder experience, why cap the AI? Our shareholders do not have caps! Let’s dream bigger. This may also increase motivation of the staff! Lastly, it wasn’t cool to adjust the managers AI calculations after the year had already been completed. This did not align with our Be Real B3. It’s perfectly fine to make changes, just give people more of a heads up than after the year is already completed and weeks before it was supposed to be paid. This was our worst miss in my time with the company.

title: Used to be Great
pros: Crown Castle has great benefits.
cons: Senior leadership no longer has a clue what to do. The company hemorrhages talent in key positions and claims that the turnover is normal. If it's so normal to lose key talent then why is the company's number one customer so upset about performance? The company refuses to adjust to the demands of the market to keep people and when the people are gone they just expect the remaining drones to keep it up. Crown used to be centered around it's B3 values but now the key phrase is "Shareholder Value". It's all the leadership cares about. Employees to cut or ignore are just a statistic and nothing else. If it doesn't increase shareholder value then it's worthless to the company.

title: Employee
pros: There is a lot of growth. The members of the senior management team truly care about issues affecting the employees and want to fix them if they are able to find out about the problems. Great culture overall.
cons: Because the company is growing so fast, there are a few entry level managers that got promoted into their positions before they were ready and they are not being properly trained.

title: NOT a great place to work
pros: great benefits, lots of food perks
cons: Staff seemingly friendly but many backstabbers, gossipers. No room for advancement, very lame, inexperienced middle management. Reminded me of high school....popularity contest. Laid back atmosphere but don't let it fool you; there is lots of drama going on in the background. Office very quiet because most employees are afraid to talk lest it be construed in a negative manner. Way too PC. Management encourages you to speak up but when you do, there goes your career. HR supports management no matter how badly they fail. If an employee is not liked, management writes you up for bogus, nit-picky reasons. Only favored employees EXCEED company expectations.

title: One of the best
pros: I have been with several companies throughout my career and Crown is the best by far. The level of talent they bring in is exceptional. The company does a very nice job treating their employees like real people, not just workers. The benefits are great and the culture is relaxed yet professional. The company's leaders are absolutely fantastic. You can honestly feel comfortable knowing that you are being led by intelligent and caring people that know their industry as well as anyone. They are taking the company in the right direction.
cons: Vacation policy could be a bit more generous.

title: Great Insurance
pros: Great Insurance and benefits, paid time off, and flexible hybrid schedules.
cons: Growing pains. Crown Castle is experiencing tremendous growth, presenting challenges with adequately managing resources. Not very front-line-employee friendly. Their employee recognition program is made by Bonusly rewards. With enough Bonusly points, you can order merchandise from the company. I doubt the ELT trades in Bonusly points.

title: 'Start-up' like without the capital constraints.
pros: Progressive work style. Open to new ideas. Creating in-roads further into the 5G carrier space. Lots of room to advance career. Very supportive of employee training opportunities. Competitive pay and excellent benefits package. Yearly bonus based on company wide performance*. *Positive or Negative depending on if you find the other departments to be pulling their weight.
cons: At times, ridiculous timeline expectations for work completion. Irresponsible handling of issues without any nuance. Preference towards heavy handed, sweeping policy changes company wide, rather than a more regional and nuanced approach to actually address local issues. In such a hurry to acquire work that they don't realize when current workload is overburdening the regional employee base. Near constant process change implementation in an effort to find 'just the right one', only for it to be scrapped and completely revamped in one or two years.

title: Rapidly declining culture
pros: Benefits including Bonus and RSUs Great people to work with on some teams
cons: Toxic leadership in some departments Hybrid work schedule Too much hierarchy and focus on titles instead of promoting true collaboration

title: Change isn't always good.
pros: Before all of the growth, Crown Castle was a great company to work for - very friendly and loving. This may still be the case in some areas but not here. The pay is okay and the benefits are outstanding, but that is about it.
cons: Company grew too large too quickly due to several portfolio acquisitions. Not enough head count was provided and requests for change were often ignored. Director level and senior management are cliquey and gossipy, and if you have a black mark on your record for any reason you will be written up (often just to get you out of there).

title: Growing Pains
pros: Steady industry. 401k match. Tuition reimbursement. Most individuals are pleasant to work with. LinkedIn Learning.
cons: Not a lot of opportunity for growth or movement unless you have the ability to relocate to corporate locations. Culture is not consistent across areas or districts. Seems to be a hiring freeze on the Tower side - not backfilling for full time positions or making much of an effort to keep good employees. Change in bonus structure which will greatly impact some individuals who probably count on that every year. Budget cuts that take away from a lot of the added benefits we all used to enjoy and love about working here. Limited work from home policy. Favoritism and a “who you know” mentality is still very much a thing in the hiring process.

title: Project Management Review
pros: They trust their employees fully and do not micro-manage. Individuals are empowered to make informed business decisions on their own. At the same time, team work is encouraged and is fostered with team building exercises- this helps create good morale and trust within the team. While traveling, they make sure we are comfortable and don't skimp on expenses. The company also believes in providing a comfortable work atmosphere with amenities that other companies don't typically provide.
cons: Employees are expected to manage very heavy workloads. There are a lot of internal reports/metrics/internal responsibilities that have to be managed, in addition to managing the external customers. The Project Manager is responsible for managing the deliverables of the company's other departments, but has no influence over those departments to enact change. Perception, politics, and personality are the primary basis for evaluating an employee's effectiveness, the same as or even more than the individual's actual job performance. Contractors are treated as second-class citizens to direct employees in some aspects.

title: Great Culture
pros: I definitely feel appreciated for my efforts via good pay, good benefits, good PTO, bonus, and stock. Management encourages ownership and empowerment to get the job done. Lots of opportunities across the country. Big focus on training lately is a huge plus. I feel that this will continue to be a long, fruitful relationship.
cons: EOM can be rough in the field, but we all understand why. The transition with all the new acquisitions has caused some challenges on the internal IT side (applications, etc) but it's starting to come together nicely.

title: Not enough people from failed Google projects
pros: Used to be an excellent place to work
cons: Crown Castle entered the Fiber industry with a billion dollar bet. It was shortsighted and sent the company from great, to just toxic almost over night. New hires from Google and other fiber companies have tailspun a once good company into a civil war: Fiber vs Every other department. Now, the Fiber management team is not only experts in Fiber, they mettle in every other departments business. Which by the way, Fiber and Small are not profitable nor are they going to be.

title: This place is amazing!
pros: The company fosters growth from within. Leadership encourages decision making at a local level but also provides proper guidance when needed. Insurance is great and employee engagement and culture are top notch. If you initially hire as a contractor / vendor just remember to work hard, dont cause problems with others in the workplace and stay true to the B3 values.
cons: The process to hire and transition from vendor/contractor status until you get a full time opportunity. However, it serves a purpose.

title: Good company, good benefits and great group of people.
pros: Good benefits, work life balance is great, people like working for the company and it shows because everyone has can do and positive attitude. The managers I've worked with and work for have been great. A lot of the employees have been with the company 10+ years so retention is fairly high. Overall the company cares about their employees and you can tell that people are happy to be working here.
cons: Needs to improve career development program and should have classes/courses available to improve skills. Opportunity for advancement may take years because no one leaves.

title: If you can think for yourself this isn't the company for you. If your a "sheeple" you'll fit right in.
pros: The only good thing to being an employee is the really nice benefit package they offer.
cons: Because of the really good benefits they offer. They feel they can pay the employees way below the industry standard and even less for the contractors they have working for them.

title: Project Coordinator
pros: Make your own work schedule within reason. Buy lunch from time to time. Pay is pretty good
cons: Very disorganized and a stressful place to work. Management has no experience and doesn't communicate changes clearly. No transparency and M&Ps change and are added daily by a disconnected leadership stuck behind a keyboard. They try to promote a good culture but it's far from that...most everyone there seems to be looking for a new job.

title: PK says Great Co. to be part of. Enjoyed my experience with them & wish I could continue.
pros: I felt very engaged with my decision to work for Crown Castle. I felt my work product was very good and I'm sure that the company benefited from our mutual work together. I would be very happy to work with them again in any capacity, especially since they have an office in Franklin TN, and I live down the road in Athens, TN. GO CROWN- Beat American Tower!!
cons: none, except they closed my office in Mahwah, NJ.

title: Great place to retire/ coast
pros: Good people, good work life balance. Decent company culture.
cons: High turnover/ churn in management leaves workers confused and stifles growth and innovation. 0 merit based recognition and no room for growth at current state. Not allotting for raises and promotions ensures employee retention suffers. Little to no training.

title: Absolutely hostile work environment
pros: Most of the individual contributors are fantastic and emulate the B3 culture.
cons: Inexperienced, back-stabbing, childish, immature, competitive, disrespecting level one leaders. A majority of the supervisors and managers are great but there are a handful that only care about themselves and they treat you so poorly. Not worth the health risk to work there.

title: Software Engineer
pros: Long term project planning. Great co-workers
cons: Crown preaches work life balance but does not always higher additional resources to maintain pace.

title: There are positives to Crown but no work/life balance
pros: They treat their contractors almost equal to employees. If you are under the correct guidance you can turn your job into a long-term career. There are many positions that you can apply for that are not directly related to the field you may be in.
cons: Expectations are too lofty if you are in the wrong position or under the wrong project manager. I was taking on other roles that were not in my job description and I was not recognized for my efforts by management. The organization was not managed by the best or the brightest.

title: Inconsistencies Across the Company
pros: Crown Castle has excellent medical/dental/vision benefits
cons: The company's bottom line is $$$; not it's people. Executive team is out of touch with much of their employee base Strategies, B3 values, Smart & Fast are a joke Management is inconsistent from dept to dept, location to location For such a large and widespread company, available positions only show up in a few places Despite being a tele communications company, working from home is not encouraged or consistently allowed

title: Not what it used to be
pros: Benefits are fair. Work schedule is flexible.
cons: Culture seems to be in decline and leadership seems to be out of touch with that. One cannot just say "this is our culture" and it suddenly exists. Cutting jobs and incentives has been a huge blow to morale. Depending on where you are in the organization, there are cliques, and not being in one of those can change your experience here (project assignments, work load, recognition, etc.).

title: Incredible Company & Place To Work!
pros: Crown Castle has a phenomenal leadership team, and a great environment/culture. The company is very family oriented. Crown Castle also compensates very well, has great benefits, and is generous with paid time off. The leadership team and stakeholders also put a major emphasis on setting their employees up for retirement.
cons: With all of the great talent here, it can be hard to stand out! But this is not a bad thing! Surrounding yourself around talented professionals will only help better your own skills and knowledge.

title: Great company, culture and benefits; work to do on diversity and inclusion
pros: Crown Castle's care for their employees is visible in every decision made from the top down. The culture puts people first, and encourages ownership and accountability. The potential for growth here is outstanding. I really enjoy working here, despite the occasional blips.
cons: The attention and devotion to advancing diversity and inclusion initiatives is minimal, despite repeated requests from employees. It doesn't seem like the leadership hears this need for support and direct action loud enough, which is very disappointing. Some traditional policies and structures make it difficult to promote new ideas, which I attribute to the lack of training for middle managers.

title: Poor Re-org
pros: The benefits are good. The people that you work with day to day are top quality.
cons: Another Re-org that is poorly thought out and implemented. They now have employees working on west coast time while living on the east coast. No work life balance. The upper managers put in charge of this move are woefully in over their heads. Customer obsession is preached, but not attainable when working across three time zones.

title: anonymous
pros: Standard benefits Medical, Dental, and company match 401K. PTO. Paid Cell phone. Company truck and tools. Flexible schedule
cons: Ridiculous micromanagement and nepotism. Most managers have never climbed a tower ever. GPS installed in the truck so they know where you are at all times. They talk about having this Crown Culture its not there with a high turnover rate. So much for the open door policy. Keep your head down and if you speak up about management issues is does not go over well with the good old boys.

title: Tenured employees no longer valued
pros: Good benefits, fast-paced environment, lots of locations
cons: Leadership has no problem dismissing tenured employees who have dedicated their careers to making Crown successful. It used to be that every employee mattered. Now when ranking priorities, employee satisfaction is literally at the bottom of the list.

title: Experiencing needed change
pros: Strong growth industry (Crown is situated nicely to profit), friendly co-workers and results driven
cons: Experiencing cultural/process/business change that is uncomfortable for some employees. Rapid growth takes time to integrate.

title: Fantastic Executives - Some Poor Middle Management
pros: There are a few companies with better executive management than Crown Castle. The culture in general is fantastic and the benefits are second to none. It’s fantastic working for executives that don’t say one thing and preach constantly one thing and then act another way. That’s very unique and refreshing. They truly live by what they preach. Unfortunately their constant preaching of good culture doesn’t always seem to soak in for some management throughout the company. While the senior executives truly mean what they say as far as good culture is concerned, I wonder if some high/middle-management treat these ideas as mere internal marketing slogan’s but don’t truly live it themselves. This seems more true in regions further away from the headquarters in Houston. If you can work at Crown Castle in Houston you will be very fortunate. Fantastic individuals and lots of great memories of working there in Houston. I know I mixed in some cons here.
cons: It’s hard to come up with these as it feels that executive management is absolutely intent on making it a great place to work and are doing everything in their power to make it so. I remember when the executives found out about one high-level manager who was clearly out of step with the good Crown culture (unbelievable ego and his disrespect of others lower than him was ridiculous) and got rid of him immediately as fast as they could. It’s fantastic. And it sent the signal that they protect no one whose behavior is bad. I absolutely loved it. if only they could find all of the managers whose words actions and egos don’t always align with the culture that’s being preached. I’ve met middle/high-level managers in other regions that seem to have bigger egos than the entire executive management team put together (which, ironically don’t seem to have any ego at all). I remember one director getting rid of one of the hardest working, kindest individuals I’ve ever worked with. The employee was super helpful even when he really didn’t have time to be (as was evidenced by his constantly working weekends). He was promoted, then afterward, told the director he was having qualms about his own ability to do the job. Instead of giving his old job back (which he was ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE AT), he was immediately fired. Unreal ego trip. NOT A SINGLE EXECUTIVE WOULD HAVE CONDONED THAT AND WOULD HAVE BEEN HORRIFIED OF LEARNING OF SUCH TERRIBLE TREATMENT OF SUCH A KIND, helpful, high-performing individual). He was an encyclopedia of knowledge about his job and trained several others. This was not in Houston.

title: Opportunity
pros: Employee culture makes it easy to work, learn and grow in a challenging environment. Industry demand and early decision makers have fueled the financial position and growth of this company.
cons: Antiquated systems and tools have created blind spots, making it difficult for leadership to effectively manage the business. A never ending cycle of system enhancements and process changes has been implemented over the years to band aid the issues. These constant changes make it difficult for employees to adjust and clearly see the vision of the company.

title: Crown is a great place to work and the company goals demand the best talent.
pros: I have been with Crown for almost 4 years. There has been a lot of change in that short amount of time. We are at a turning point in history with the digital transformation age in process. Our opportunities are endless. What an exciting time to be with this company!
cons: At times the work can be very demanding however the long term accomplishments will be worth it.

title: Could be much better
pros: Competitive benefits-appears focused on I&D
cons: Preaches work-life balance but forces 3 days in office. Let teammates work from where they work best-let leaders manage their team instead of EMT mandating people be in the office. Hire the best candidates instead of hiring to check the I&D box or eliminating candidates that want to work remotely. No evidence of the benefit to implementing career framework. Offer voluntary severance-many “old timers” hanging on waiting for it-cut your losses and bring in new talent by offering them a severance instead of the ESSP.

title: Best Company Culture Out There
pros: Our culture is what keeps me here. You don't realize how good you have it until you hear about the environments others work in. Culture isn't just a poster on the wall here. It permeates everything we do, from core business functions to our benefits to the way employees are treated. It's a wonderful place to work.
cons: There's a pretty flat structure here, so it's not easy to move up. I also think the lower positions should be paid more because those salaries aren't as competitive.

title: Crown Castle is a terrific place to work!
pros: 99% of the time you can count on the person with whom you are working to be doing his/her best to do what is right for the company. Crown is growing rapidly and there are lots of opportunities for personal development and advancement. Great benefits including 401K match and stock grants.
cons: Honestly, this is a great place to work. Truly. Nothing bad to say.

title: Great company
pros: Crown is a great place to work. People rarely leave the company. You will be busy, but the company culture is great.
cons: There is a definite lack of diversity. They do not always walk the talk, lots of flowery buzz words are used by the EMT but that isn't translated into the day to day operations. Good ole boy culture.

title: Best Company on the Planet
pros: People actually value other people here- genuinely. Company is led by a wonderful, sharp, group of executives who are dedicated to maintaining the best culture on the planet. Are there flaws- of course. No where is it perfect. You won't find a company anywhere that's more dedicated to making its employees happy. Tower business is the best industry to be in and this is the best company to work for in the industry. Do not turn down an offer if you get it. You will never have any idea what you missed out on- seriously.
cons: Imperfect people who are trying their best.

title: Coordinator
pros: Crown as a company is great. They take care of their employees.
cons: Upper management in particular offices like to make their own rules and does not always abide to the values of crown. Employees are scared to speak up in fear of retaliation. They hire friends and family members and push them ahead of those who have been there for a while and have been asking for an opportunity to move forward.

title: Proud to be part of this team!
pros: Excellent pay, benefits, and culture. Crown is growing, but still manages to stay focused on employees - they realize that happy employees make happy customers. They are invested in their corporate values and mission. A lot is expected of the employees and those efforts are recognized. It feels good to be part of a company and team that values and empowers their people.
cons: More established processes needed to address recent growth, but I know management and executives are aware and working on it and looking for input from people on the trenches.

title: Jay Brown Ruined it.
pros: The past. Benefits are good. Semi-flexible schedule.
cons: The future. Jay Brown really has ruined this company. It was amazing when I started and now most people in my department (that haven’t been laid-off) are either waiting to be be laid-off or are actively looking for work. I remember Crown bragging about their Glassdoor scores a few years ago so I check it out today, wow have things changed. Moral is beyond zero. Who is going to Be Accountable for this? Jay, are you going to Be an Owner and step up, or keep hiding in your truck? When I started everyone truly felt lucky to work here, and now the opposite.

title: Growing Pains with this small company
pros: CCI has good benefits and office spaces
cons: The management in minor league, comprised of JV quality players. Many just do not have enough real world experience in managing projects and people. White collar on the outside, but very blue collar on the inside. In fact, my time at CCI was the lowest professional experience in my whole career.

title: Good Depending on Location
pros: Good benefits, great profitable business.
cons: The culture is adhered to differently in different parts of the country. In Houston, people generally adhere to the culture with some exceptions. But Houston leadership is *always* in adherence to the culture. This is not the way it always is in different parts of the country unfortunately. Many leaders will get big heads from their positions. The Eastern region has lots of these, unfortunately.

title: Not the Crown It Used to Be
pros: Great 401K, benefits. Mediocre salary. Some really great people work here, some incredible people USED to work here.
cons: TERRIBLE leadership. EMT lies. No other way to say it. Company used to put its employees first. Not anymore.

title: No regard of people
pros: Pretty good benefits, decent salary, some good people to work with, can do what you want to if you suck up to the boss.
cons: truction manager

title: Was a great company
pros: Great pay, benefits and compensation.
cons: Realignment in 2020 is a disaster. Customer service is no longer prioritized, every dept. has their own priorities but seldom align to benefit the end user. No support from management, lots of pressure to perform, toxic environment, cya everyday.

title: Wonderfule Company with great opportunites for professional growth
pros: * Great co-workers * Employees are valued * Pay is great * Benefits are outstanding * Company has strong values and ethics * In house training classes * Opportunities for travel * Employee bonuses * Generous PTO
cons: * Most positions start as contract employees * Relocation is the easiest way to advance * Getting addtional staff is a long process

title: Management Challenges + Mixed Messages
pros: Generous benefit package - health and 401K.
cons: Limited growth opportunities in District offices. Employee experiences vary greatly based on quality (or lack thereof) of manager. The culture is deteriorating.

title: Big company with Big Opportunities
pros: Great training procedures that get you acclimated with the telecom industry and Crown Castle standards Your Team members will always be there to answer your questions and help you solve problems You definitely have room to move up, if you can prove that you're able to take on more responsibility Job security seemed like it was very likely when working with Crown Castle
cons: Crown Castle is currently a very customer orientated company, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. However, it seemed like at times the Customer would force Crown Castle into awkward positions in order to reach Customer goals.

title: World Class Organization
pros: The salary is not only at the top of the range in all areas that they hire in but the raise and bonus structure is very transparent and fair. Amazing culture, lots of benefits (tops in the area) and there is a managerial perspective on fairness and career development that is rarely found at any organization.
cons: This is a company with lots of high acheivers, relatively new people, and is going through an extreme growth phase. People that want consistency and the same thing day in and day out would be disappointed here.

title: Excellent Work / Life Balance
pros: Crown Castle as an organization is concerned for the well-being and work / life balance of each employee and works to make sure that you have the ability to maintain these in a healthy manner. This includes a workout gym on site, memberships to a local gym, and annual health challenges, etc. There are many of my coworkers who have been employed here for 5+ years.
cons: none that I can think of at this time. I would love to say this in a 20 word minimum.

title: Lack of Leadership
pros: Project teams work well together on the District side. Good benefits, decent pay and work life is good.
cons: If you are not a golf buddy you will get passed up for advancement. Managers always locked behind closed doors. If you are tenured or more to the point, over 40, your days are numbered. Managers say they can get two younger people for what they pay some employees.

title: Culture. Excellence. Values. Community.
pros: Vibrant culture! Pursuit of excellence. Living core values. Incredible presence in local communities. Deeply-committed executive team with world-class business & financial leadership. The "EMT" is dedicated to building an incredible company. Incredible market opportunity, positioned to capitalize on most important disruptive/emerging technologies of near-future including 5G, IoT, autonomy, increasing "intelligence everywhere" world etc. Amazing suite of benefits for employees including generous matching 401k, superior healthcare options, and new resources for learning new skills from LinkedIn Learning and Harvard.
cons: Deeper, targeted technology investment needed to optimize workplace productivity and collaboration.

title: Excellent company to work for.
pros: You can tell from the moment you start you’re being set up for success. The pay is competitive, the management teams are their to help at any moment making it a great place to work. You can tell that the company truly values you as a person and not just a number.
cons: truction manager

title: Was a great place to work
pros: PAY work-life balance overtime benefits yearly bonus Culture pre 2019
cons: truction manager

title: People-Focused Culture
pros: From the beginning of Covid, we have been working from home and will continue to do so at least through the end of the year. We were given an additional 40-hours of PTO to use on anything Covid related and the leadership team sent out a survey to get a pulse on struggles/benefits of working from home.
cons: I honestly can't think of anything. Grateful to work for such a caring company during a time like this.

title: Growing Company Changing Culture
pros: Profitable Strong Financials with Many Career Paths to explore; Good benefits and compensation
cons: Change in Culture with differing experiences depending upon the department and city in which you work. Pittsburgh vs. Houston; Operations vs. Finance vs. HR vs. Engineering vs. Sales, vs. Legal, etc. The degree of positive experience you have working here is directly dependent upon where you work and the leadership for your area. Ask around for your job's specific department to get a read.

title: Great place to work
pros: Hard work really pays off at Crown! There are a lot of opportunities for internal promotions and employees are encouraged to develop their careers. Crown also has good benefits and a great company culture. Everyone is helpful and friendly, and you're never looked down on for asking questions.
cons: They're currently in the process of integrating several acquisitions so things can get a little crazy, but hopefully the dust will settle within the next year and things will calm down

title: Great culture and assets
pros: CCI is well capitalized and financially stable. They are willing to back up sellers with investment in customers. Promises to clients are fulfilled by operations and construction. Pay is very competitive. The B3 values set a great tone for company culture.
cons: Still some growing pains, such as systems infrastructure, but these are being addressed. Learning curve for sales has been longer than in other companies.

title: I enjoyed My Time There
pros: Friendly staff; lots of learning opportunities; Decent pay; the annual company meetings are 2nd to none!; there is an 'open door' policy and they really abide by it; tons of tools for personal growth; professional environment; great bonuses.
cons: Merit often plays no part in promotions;

title: Great benefits. Trust-oriented highly ethical corporate culture. A little meeting-heavy.
pros: Great benefits. Generally flexible management to maintain quality of life. Fast growing company (small cell networks) with room to affect change.
cons: Fast growth within small cell networks organization means that there are growing pains. Structured corporate environment makes it difficult to affect change and adapt quickly to growing pains.

title: Crown is not what it appears to be
pros: Good benefits start right away
cons: Company touts it's 10% 401K, they don't tell you that you have to be employed 3 years there to get it, many employees don't last that long. Sales Mgt group is one of the worst in telecom. High sales rep churn especially with new reps, high quota and a lousy sales comp plan, only connected reps get the accounts that bill anything. Operations contractors have to wait years to get a full time position. Liberal corporate culture is shoved down employees throats, opposing viewpoints are a 1st class ticket to unemployment.

title: Great Culture and they truly care about their employees
pros: They stress ownership and accountability; most employees feel empowered. It's a fairly relaxed environment, but everyone gives 110%. The leadership team is approachable and makes an effort to travel to each of the Area's meetings.
cons: It's a flat organization with very few opportunities for advancement. Their turnover is very low which says a lot about their culture and values. It can be difficult to identify a career path.

title: Good, Solid Company
pros: The company is great to work for - great benefits, great work-life balance, great culture. Very laid-back but professional atmosphere and the company is growing every day.
cons: Nepotism definitely exists. It's not prolific, but it's there. Opportunities can be dependent on who you know instead of the qualities you bring to the table.

title: Obvious declining work environment with an obvious increase in revenue
pros: Pay was average, but benefits were fantastic. Small activities and extras for employees to steer them away from the overall overkill of work with no assistance in sight.
cons: Micromanagement/favoring of certain individuals. There is a culture that you may find similar in a high school prevalent here. The truth on management and inexperience is very obvious.

title: Started off great, but constant changing and declining morale made a toxic work environment
pros: Benefits, good office snacks, fancy coffee maker
cons: Bad middle management, poor leadership, morale is next to nothing. Most teams dislike working with one another. Constant blame game with no signs of improvement. Very little sense of a career path for most employees. little employee recognition. poor performers never get reprimanded, so why even care to put in anything beyond the bare minimum.

title: As good as it gets in the wireless industry
pros: Good benefits and great people

title: SEEKING OTHER CROWN EMPLOYEES AGAINST THE VACCINE MANDATE
pros: The salary is fair and the benefit package is good.
cons: President Biden has not issued a national mandate because the federal government has no statutory authority to do so, but Crown Castle (headquartered in TX) is strictly enforcing vaccine mandates for ALL employees, with NO exceptions. Crown Castle has refused to comply with the TX Governor's Executive Order banning vaccine mandates. All employees must submit proof of full vaccination by November 15th or be terminated and then ineligible to receive unemployment benefits. I am not against the vaccine. I have already had COVID-19 and I have natural immunity; recent research has proven that antibodies are more protective than the vaccine. The CDC confirms the vaccine will not prevent me from contracting COVID or spreading it, and the efficacy of the vaccines continues to decline. I am extremely concerned about the number of deaths and adverse events related to the mRNA vaccinations. What if I comply with Crown’s mandate and suffer cardiac issues or become disabled – what then? I also have strong personal religious convictions that leave me very conflicted about the mRNA vaccines, but Crown will not honor religious exemptions. Crown even refuses to allow any reasonable accommodations, like accepting my antibody test results, allowing me to submit regular COVID tests or to continue to work from home. I never anticipated having to face such a personal moral and ethical dilemma in my workplace. My employer is forcing me to undergo an irreversible and experimental medical treatment to feed my family and keep a roof over my head -- or destroy my life. Isn’t this a violation of my civil rights? I support a family and cannot afford to lose my job. I would like to connect with other employees who are experiencing the same relentless pressure to "hurry up and get the shot" and suffering the same immense stress my family and I are facing as we try to decide the best way forward. Please comment if you share my situation.

title: Wearing a scarlet letter
pros: Some of the most outwardly nice people I've known to work with. Clean office. Plenty of leftovers to pick through once all of the real employees get to eat.
cons: I worked here as a contractor. Anyone who has worked here will likely immediately know what I'm about to start talking about, due to how prevalent the issues are. When I first started at crown castle, as a contractor, the stock price was around $76. Now it is around $96. My purpose of stating this is not to take credit for their performance. It is to illustrate that is a company doing very well financially. Their net profit margin this year is nearly 9%. I could list more metrics, but let me save you the time and tell you that they are very good. Because of this, or maybe despite this, they have very good benefits for their REGULAR employees. For example, I overheard my colleagues complaining about having a deductible on their insurance this year. Departments have a yearly trip that they take where they spend a week elsewhere in the country and have work parties. The group I was associated with had one such week long party where the rooms at this place ran over $300 a night. They have fairly regular employer paid lunches. Generous holidays. Go look at their benefits yourself, you will be impressed. I was, anyway. However, since I was a contractor, I got none of them. No paid time off. No sick time. No holidays. When the regulars get an early day, what do the contractors get? They can leave if they want, but they have to make the time up. What if the office is flooded for two days and the contractors are explicitly told not to come to work, what happens? They don't get paid. What about the smaller stuff? Well, when the regulars get lunch, the contractors are told they have to eat AFTER everyone else. I've never in my life had anyone tell me anything like that. When they have their little non yearly office parties, the contractors get told that they can't attend. Monthly morning tea? Sorry. So, one might think then that it's all the more motivation to become a regular employee for this company with its great benefits. That may work for some. But in my experience and that of others, there are opportunites only for some. Consider a scenario--two employees start at the same time. One a young man, one a young woman. How weird would be if all of these 40+ year old managers introduced themselves to one and ignored the other? That's what happened to me. The managers were male the new employee was a female. These entry level jobs that contractors could aspire to, they're either set aside for nepotism or set aside for a particular gender. I was always told that nepotism was bad, but until I sat and heard a woman talking about how her husband directly got her brother a job, I didn't have cause to believe it. The way some landlord customers are treated are pretty abhorrent, too. I won't get into that, though.

title: Would not recommend
pros: The employees in most of the offices are great. I still talk to many people I worked with at Crown, and most of them are hardworking, knowledgeable, fun, and great to interact with in the day to day grind. The health benefits were great, compensation could be good depending on your role and team.
cons: Leadership- There are some good managers to be found throughout the organization and you can sniff them out pretty easily, but overall there is a void of leadership within Crown Castle. It is evident that the sub-par leadership is not confined to one area, team, or group. It is an issue across the organization. Read the reviews on this site, they are more honest than the employee survey. It is also not surprising to see the leadership attempt to cover up the negative reviews with the positive ones. Communication- Leadership at Crown Castle SAYS the right things (or says nothing at all), but it is in their actions, or lack thereof, where you see the truth. The B3’s are talked up from management, but the actions behind them are lacking. Growth/Advancement- this is a “Who you know” culture. I personally have seen multiple roles filled by people with limited background for said role, while those with a proven track record of success are passed over for irrelevant reasons. Diversity- there isn’t much. Training- It is a sink or swim environment…or maybe float in a group with people that can help keep your head above water, hoping someone in a leadership role does not push you under. Culture – I sought out Crown Castle as a place to work when I started there. It was known as a great place to work and have a career. Somewhere you wanted to be. At this point the line to get out is longer than the line to get in. Many people have begun to leave, or left, and leadership will say it is because they “are not on board with change” . Many of these people (of which I am one) are more comfortable changing their entire employment than staying in an environment and culture that has become increasingly toxic and stressful. They are fine with change, it is poor leadership, lack of vision, and lack of support that they were looking to leave.

title: Even Apartheid States are Full of Nice People
pros: Snacks in the break room. People are nice.
cons: Nice people are part of the problem. Because too many of CC’s full time employees go with the flow CC gets away with a lot of mistreatment. Ultimately CC operates with a high contractor headcount, makes it difficult for contractors to transition to full time and makes it difficult for full time employees to get promoted to avoid paying benefits for many of its employees and avoid significant raises. Contractors are hired with the promise of a full time job within 3 months of hire but doesn’t disclose that in order to convert to full time, the contract employee will have to wait for an opening and proceed through the application and an extensive interview process. This is true even if the contractor is applying for their own job. An existing internal employee applying from within the office or from another office and family members of existing employees will receive preference over the contract employee even if the contract employee is applying for the job they are already doing as a contractor. Some people have been “contractors” for 10 years. If you move jobs bc your spouse got a job in another city, you may have to accept a contractor role and CC will drop you from benefits. When I was working for CC about 45% of the workforce was contract. They notified all of the contractors with about 5 working days warning that as of the following Friday all contractors would be let go company-wide. Contractors are treated as second class citizens by management. They are required to stay and continue working while full time employees leave for the company Christmas party and other company events. How awkward to watch everyone get up and walk out to go to a holiday party while murmuring apologies to the contractors as you pass. Existing full time employees have to go through the same process to get promoted.l that contractors have to go through to get hired. Managers do not advocate for their employees to be promoted even within their own group because, just like everyone else, employees at Crown are just coasting through for a paycheck and no one wants to call attention to themselves. Some full time employees are given annual bonuses while for others it is left to the discretion of their manager to give them a piece of his pie. Even if the bonus is based upon a project that you worked on, you will likely not receive a bonus unless you are management and the manager’s primary role is to “assign” work. CC attempted a leadership development program. The education includes teaching managers to teach their people that high performers often don’t take vacation days. The false statistic referenced is one of many false statistics CC uses to employee a workaholic culture. The executives primarily tour from office to office like the English royal family visiting their colonies. On those days you will receive a free lunch in exchange for a healthy dose of culture propoganda. I’m not sure what else they do.
